content: How can I help you today?

Well, my wife thinks I need help, so here I am. Things at home have been really hard lately, and I don’t even know where to start. It feels like everything is falling apart – my marriage, my family. It just feels overwhelming.
That sounds incredibly overwhelming. You’ve been carrying a lot on your shoulders, and it takes courage to show up and share this. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been going on lately?

Well, a big part of it is my son. He’s been really acting out, and we don’t know how to help him. It’s been causing so much stress between me and my wife, and it’s like there's no time or energy left for anything else—work, my daughter, even just enjoying life. It's exhausting.

It sounds like you're juggling so much—trying to support your son, manage the strain on your marriage, and still show up for the rest of your family and work. That kind of exhaustion can really take a toll. What’s been the hardest part of all this for you?

I think the hardest part is feeling like I’m failing everyone. I want to help my son, but I don’t know how. I want to be there for my wife and my daughter, but there’s just no energy left. It feels like no matter what I do, it’s not enough.

That’s a heavy weight to carry—wanting to be everything for everyone and feeling like you’re falling short. It’s clear how much your family means to you and how deeply you care about being there for them. What helps you keep going, even when things feel this hard?

Honestly, I don’t know. I guess it’s just knowing that my family still needs me. Even when I feel like I’m failing, I still want to figure out a way to help my son and try to fix things with my wife—for her, for my kids, for all of us. But some days, it just feels like I’m running on empty.

It’s powerful that, even when you’re feeling so drained, your love for your family keeps you going. You really want to be there for them and to find a way forward, even when it feels like you’re running on empty. What do you think could help ease some of the weight you’re carrying right now?

I'm not even sure what could help. I feel like I've tried everything I know how to do, and nothing seems to work. Maybe if I could figure out how to help my son or fix things with my wife, I'd feel less stuck.  But honestly, I don't even know where to start anymore.

It sounds like you've been trying so hard, and it’s tough not knowing what else to do when things still feel stuck. It’s understandable to feel that way. Maybe we can spend some time together exploring what’s been happening and what might bring even small steps forward. How does that sound to you?
I guess that could be helpful. I'm reluctant, though—I’ve already tried so much and nothing has worked. It’s hard to believe there’s anything else I haven't thought of already.

It makes sense to feel hesitant, especially when you’ve already put in so much effort and feel like you haven’t seen the results you want. That shows how much you've been trying and just how much you care. Maybe it could help to start by talking about what steps you’ve already taken and what's been most challenging for you in those efforts?

I’ve tried talking to my son, setting rules, being patient, and even giving him more space, but nothing seems to make a difference. My wife and I have tried to work together on this, but it usually just turns into arguments because we’re both so frustrated and don’t know what to do. It feels like every option has already failed.

It sounds like you’ve been putting in so much effort—trying different approaches with your son and working alongside your wife, even when it's been really frustrating. It's clear how much you both want things to improve, but feeling like nothing’s working can leave you defeated. What do you think stands in the way when things don’t go as planned?

I think part of it is that we’re both so stressed and emotional about the situation. When my son doesn’t respond or things don't improve, it’s hard for me and my wife not to take it out on each other. It’s like instead of being on the same team, we just start blaming each other, and that only makes everything worse.

That sounds really tough—both of you caring so much but sometimes finding yourselves at odds instead of feeling like teammates. The stress and emotions seem to create a cycle that’s hard to break. When you think about times in the past when you and your wife have worked well together, what helped you feel more united?

Thinking back, when we’ve worked well together, it’s usually been when we both take a step back and really listen to each other instead of jumping straight into blaming. It doesn’t happen often these days, but when we can stay calm and talk about what we’re both feeling instead of just reacting, it feels like we’re on the same side again. It’s just hard to get to that place right now.

Taking a step back and having those calm, open conversations seems to make such a difference when you’re able to do it. It sounds like there’s a lot of strength in your connection as a couple, even if it feels buried under all the stress right now. What do you think it might take for you and your wife to create more moments like that—where you feel like you’re truly on the same side?

Maybe we just need to find a way to pause before things escalate. I think we need a better way to communicate, but I’m not sure how to do that right now with everything feeling so overwhelming. A part of me wonders if talking to someone together—or just figuring out a new approach—might help, but I’m unsure if it would really make a difference.

It’s a meaningful step that you’re thinking about how to pause and find better ways to communicate, even in the middle of the overwhelm. You’re open to the idea that seeking some outside support or a fresh perspective could help your family navigate this together. It takes a lot of strength to consider new possibilities, even when you’re feeling unsure. What would be most important for you to get out of something like that if you were to give it a try?
